10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111984 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the Cu/Zn/Al and Cu/Zn/Ga precursors prepared by (a) coprecipitation (where, i, ii and iii are standards for Cu6Al2(OH)16CO3 (JCPDS#37–0630), aurichalcite (JCPDS#17–0743) and malachite (JCPDS#41–1309), respectively) and (b) AMOST method (inset: expanded 2θ region between 33–50 °). Fig 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of different precursors. (a) Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-CP; (b) Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP; (c) Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDH; (d) Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDH; (e) Cu0.4Zn0.3Ga0.3-LDH; (f) Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDH. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) XRD patterns, (b) N2 sorption isotherms and (c) H2-TPR of the calcined Cu-Zn-Ga catalysts prepared by CP and AMOST methods. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) CO-TPD and (b) H2-TPD profiles of (i) Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP, (ii) Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-CP, (iii) Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDO, (iv) Cu0.4Zn0.3Ga0.3-LDO, (v) Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO and (vi) Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDO. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) Plot of STY of methanol as a function of reaction time on stream for CuZnGa or Al based catalysts for methanol synthesis at 250 °C and 3 MPa pressure using 200 mg of the catalyst. The feed composition of the syngas was V H 2 : V CO : V CO 2 : V Ar = 17.3 : 6.3 : 2.1 : 0.3 and the total gas flow was kept at 26 mL/min. The catalysts were in-situ pre-reduced at 250 °C for 4 h before syngas treatment. (b) Plots of steady state STY after 50 h of reaction and % stability in STY for different catalysts. The small amount of promoter has shown increase in the methanol formation rate by several folds. Hence, hydrotalcite having sufficient trivalent cations are preferred; however, traditional coprecipitation route often leads to poor Cu dispersion owing to higher cationic charge in the layered structure that result in aggregation of the sheets. The present paper reports synthesis of porous, nanostructured Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 catalysts from pure phase hydrotalcite precursors by using aqueous miscible organic solvent treatment method. The 20% Ga containing catalyst showed ca. 2.5-fold increase in both surface area and % dispersion of the exposed Cu as compared to that prepared from standard coprecipitation method with similar composition. The stabilization induced by mutual dispersion of Cu, Zn and Ga components in the exfoliated sheets resulted in confinement of the Cu particle size up to 5 nm in the spent catalyst. The best performing catalyst of the series, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO exhibited STY of 762 mg•gCat −1•h−1 for methanol formation from syngas which was decreased by only 8.6% during 50 h of the reaction on stream. Further, it was revealed that, Ga is more conductive to stabilization of Cu as compared to Al, resulting in 23% higher methanol formation rate as compared to the Al containing catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Layer double hydroxides methanol synthesis Cu dispersion AMOST method confinement effect 1 Introduction The general raw materials for synthesis of methanol are coal, natural gas as well as biomass and other renewable materials [1]. Besides utility as direct fuel, methanol holds vast industrial importance owing to the large variety of applications it caters to. Due to its industrial importance and high consumption, numerous investigations have been carried out in order to improve the methanol production process. It is widely known that methanol is produced industrially from syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) with addition of small amounts of CO2 [2, 3]. The main issue of concern with this process is the performance of the state-of-the-art Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst which often leads to a low conversion, operates under drastic reaction conditions and susceptible to the deactivation via sintering of metallic Cu [4]. Since past couple of decades, many research groups are involved in designing of Cu/ZnO based catalysts by using different preparation techniques and varying catalyst compositions [5–9]. The composition of the precursor phase indeed affects the distribution of Cu species and the synergy between Cu-ZnO in the methanol synthesis catalysts [10, 11]. Hence, designing the new synthetic approach for Cu/ZnO based catalyst from pure phase precursor is of greater interest. The synthesis of CuZn-hydroxycarbonates via coprecipitation method often leads to the mixed phase precursors, viz., malachite, hydrozincite, hydrotalcite and aurichalcite, which renders Cu/ZnO catalysts with low dispersion and surface area of exposed Cu, larger crystallite size of Cu and poor reducibility owing to inhomogeneous microstructures generated from different precursors that eventually lead to a declined catalytic performance [7, 12]. Further, auxiliary promoter ions, viz., Al3+, Ga3+ have already shown improved catalytic performance by several folds as compared to binary Cu/ZnO system [13, 14]. It is noteworthy that these promoter ions are difficult to incorporate in the Cu-Zn based pure phase hydroxy carbonates, like, malachite, zinc malachite or hydrozincite because of their charge mismatch [14]. As a result, the promoter ions are not homogeneously substituted with Cu2+/Zn2+ ions to form a single precursor phase and hence, it is difficult to achieve the atomic level dispersion between Al, Cu, and Zn components in the precursor prepared by the co-precipitation method. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) often termed as hydrotalcites, contain cationic brucite-like layers with intercalated anions, viz., carbonates, nitrates and water molecules between the layers [15, 16]. These layered materials are generally expressed as, [M2+ 1− x M3+ x (OH)2](A n −) x / n •mH2O; where, A n − refers to the anions neutralizing the divalent (M2+) as well as trivalent (M3+) metal cations present in the layers giving rise to the atomic level dispersion of all the constituent metal ions [17]. Recently, LDHs have attained greater attention owing to their improved microstructure properties and the flexibility of incorporating desired M2+ and M3+ cations in the layered structure [18, 19]. In the LDH based precursors, the presence of Cu, Zn and Al or Ga in the single cationic layer lead to the enhanced dilution of Cu that has already shown improved catalytic activity as well as stability for methanol synthesis [20, 21]. However, the LDHs prepared from traditional coprecipitation route are often aggregated owing to high hydrophilicity and charge density that result in poor surface area [22]. Wang and co-workers [22, 23] came up with a simple method, aqueous miscible organic solvent treatment (AMOST) to prepare LDHs that exhibit enhanced textural properties, especially, BET surface area as compared to the pristine ones. The AMOST method included additional step of treatment of the final coprecipitated wet slurry with organic solvent, viz., acetone or methanol. It was found that, the treatment of aqueous miscible organic solvent lead to thin and highly dispersed nanosheets or even single layers upon exfoliation. Hence, in the present paper, the Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 based catalysts were prepared from CuZnGa-hydrotalcite precursors prepared by following AMOST method. The calcined catalysts were successfully utilized for industrially important, syngas hydrogenation to methanol. The systematic comparison of microstructure properties and catalytic performance has been demonstrated with Al based catalysts prepared by using AMOST method as well as Ga based catalysts prepared by using standard coprecipitation method. Combining the characterization data before and after the reaction and the activity evaluation results, the structure activity relationship has been established. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All the chemicals used were AR grade. Na2CO3, NaOH and ethanol were purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Zr(NO3)4•5H2O, Al(NO3)3•9H2O and Cu(NO3)2•3H2O were procured from China National Pharmaceutical Group Co., Ltd. Ga(NO3)3 was purchased from Aladdin Reagents Co., Ltd. Deionized water was used for all the experiments. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Cu/Zn/Ga based catalysts containing constant 40 mol% of Cu were prepared from pure phase LHD precursors by using aqueous miscible organic solvent treatment (AMOST) method. In order to compare the effect of the promoter, the Cu/Zn/Al-LDH based catalyst was also prepared from AMOST method. Further, for comparison of the synthesis method, the Cu/Zn/Al and Cu/Zn/Ga catalysts with similar composition of constituent elements to those prepared via AMOST route were also prepared by conventional coprecipitation (CP) route. 2.2.1 Preparation of Cu/Zn/Ga-LDO and Cu/Zn/Al-LDO catalysts by AMOST method The LDH precursors were prepared by following the coprecipitation route with slight modification as described in detail by Wang, et al [22, 23]. Typically, the Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, Zn(NO3)2•6H2O and Ga(NO3)3 salts were dissolved in 50 mL deionised water in the desired proportions keeping C[Cu2+]+C[Zn2+]+C[Ga3+] = 1 M (where, CCu=0.4, CZn=0.3–0.5 and CGa=0.1–0.3). The mixed solution of NaOH (1.5 M) and Na2CO3 (C[Na2CO3] = 2C[Ga3+]) was used as a precipitating agent. Both the metal salts and base solutions were added to a beaker containing 100 mL of deionized water at room temperature with constant stirring while maintaining the pH = 10±0.2 by controlling the flow rates. After complete addition of metal salts solution, the precipitates were aged for 15 h followed by filtering and washing for 5 times to remove the undesired ions. The obtained filter cake was dispersed again in 200 ml of methanol and aged at room temperature for 2 h followed by suction filtration and drying (at 50 °C). The obtained LDH precursors were denoted as CuxZnyGaz-LDH (where, x=0.4, y=0.3–0.5 and z=0.1–0.3). The synthesis of Al based catalyst, Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDH was prepared by following the same AMOST procedure by replacing Ga(NO3)3 with Al(NO3)3. The obtained Ga and Al based LDH precursors were further transformed into oxides by calcination at 330 °C for 3 h and the obtained catalysts were designated as CuxZnyGaz-LDO and CuxZnyAlz-LDO, respectively. 2.2.2 Preparation of Cu/Zn/Ga and Cu/Zn/Al catalysts by coprecipitation method The Al3+ and Ga3+ doped Cu/ZnO catalysts were prepared by using standard constant pH coprecipitation method as described elsewhere in detail [24]. Typically, 4.83 g Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, 5.95 g Zn(NO3)2•6H2O and 2.56 g Ga(NO3)3 (Cu/Zn/Ga mol%=40/40/20) were dissolved in 50 mL deionised water. A solution of 1.5 M Na2CO3 was taken in a separate beaker. The above two solutions were added into the beaker containing 100 mL of deionized water under vigorous stirring at 65 °C using peristaltic pump. During the addition, the pH was maintained at 6.5 by controlling the flow rate of the two solutions. After the precipitation was completed, the slurry was stirred continuously for 2 h and then washed and filtered repeatedly for 5 times to remove undesired ions. The dried (80 °C, 12 h) product was calcined in a muffle furnace at 330 °C for 3 h to obtain Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP. Likewise, Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-CP was prepared by following the same method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization methods The N2 physisorption measurements of the catalysts were performed using Beishide 3H-2000PS2 apparatus at -196 °C after degassing the samples under vacuum at 240 °C for 4 h. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the precursors and the catalysts was performed by Rigaku SmartLab SE photoelectron spectrometer using CuKα (λ = 1.541862 nm, 40 Kv, 40 mA) laser source. The XRD patterns were recorded in the scanning angle (2θ) from 5°-80° at 8°/min in the steps of 0.01°. The crystallite size was analyzed by using MDI Jade 6.5 software according to the following formula: d ( X R D ) = κ λ β cos θ Where, d is the average particle size, λ is the X-ray wavelength, κ is the particle shape factor (constant value is 0.94), θ is the angle between the incident ray and the crystal plane, and β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM). The TEM (transmission electron microscope) images were taken on JEOL-2100F microscope equipped with accessories such as X-ray energy spectrometer and electron energy loss instrument (EELS) at acceleration voltage 200 kV and point resolution of 0.19 nm. The elemental composition was estimated using Shimadzu ICPS-7500 plasma emission spectrometer. The H2-TPR (temperature programmed reduction) was performed using a chemical adsorption apparatus (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920). Typically, a 20 mg of the catalyst was weighed and placed into a U-shaped quartz tube reactor, and purge with N2 at constant temperature of 300 °C for 30 min at a gas flow rate of 40 mL/min to remove impurities and moisture adsorbed by the sample. After cooling to 50 °C, the gas was switched to 10% H2/Ar at the flow rate of 50 mL/min. After achieving the stable baseline, the temperature was increased at the rate of 10 °C/min to 600 °C. During this process, the changes observed in the H2 signal are detected by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD). N2O-TPD (temperature programmed desorption) titrations were performed on the AutoChem II 2920 instrument. Firstly, the fresh catalysts (40 mg) were reduced in 10% H2/Ar mixture until 450 °C is attained and the amount of hydrogen consumption was denoted as X. Then the reactor was then purged with N2 and cooled to 50 °C. The N2O gas was used to re-oxidized surface metallic copper atoms to Cu2O. Finally, a pulse of pure H2 was passed over the catalyst and the surface Cu2O were reduced in the pulse of pure H2 and the amount of consumed H2 was denoted as Y. By quantifying the amount of consumed H2, the dispersion of Cu and exposed Cu surface area of the catalyst were calculated by the following equations, respectively. D C u = 2 Y X × 100 ( % ) S A C u = ( 2 n H 2 × N ) / ( 1.4 × 10 19 × W ) ( m 2 / g ) d C u = 104.25 D C u ( n m ) Where, d Cu is crystallite size of Cu, D cu is dispersion of Cu, SA Cu is exposed Cu surface area, n H 2 is the moles of consumed H2, W is the weight of the catalyst, N is Avogadro's constant (6.02 × 1023 atoms mol−1), and 1.4 × 1019 is the number of Cu atoms per square meter. The H2-TPD (temperature programmed desorption) analysis was performed using Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 to analyze the H2 chemisorption performance of the catalysts. A100 mg of the catalyst was reduced at 250 °C in 10% H2/Ar for 2 h and then cooled to 50 °C in Ar atmosphere. Then, the gas was switched to 10% H2/Ar mixture gas, after the saturation adsorption of H2, the physically adsorbed gas was removed by purging with Ar gas. The amount of chemisorbed H2 was detected by heating the sample up to 800 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min by TCD. The CO-TPD (temperature programmed desorption) was performed on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 using 40 mg of the sample which was pre-heated at 300 °C for 30 min in a nitrogen atmosphere. After the sample was cooled to 250 °C, the gas was switched to a reducing 10% H2/Ar gas. After 30 minutes of reduction, the sample was purged with Ar for 20 minutes and the temperature was lowered to 50 °C. The gas was switched to a 10% CO/Ar mixed gas for CO adsorption. The Ar gas was used to remove the physically adsorbed CO gas. After the stabilization of TCD signal, the TPD was performed by increasing the temperature to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The amount of CO desorption was detected by TCD. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation method The catalyst activity evaluation was carried out on a high-pressure double-channel fixed-bed micro-reactor (Xiamen Better Work Intelligent Technology Co., Ltd.). The oxide catalysts were compressed to pellets, crushed and sieved to 40–60 mesh for testing the catalytic activity. A 0.2 g of the catalyst and 0.2 g of spherical SiO2 (40–60 mesh) were evenly mixed and then placed in a central constant temperature zone of the quartz tube reactor. Firstly, the catalysts were reduced by using H2 and N2 mixed gas (where, V(H2)/V(N2) = 1:4) keeping the total gas flow rate of 50 mL/min. The temperature was raised to 250 °C at 2 °C/min and maintained for 4 h at atmospheric pressure. After naturally cooling to 50 °C, the reducing gas was switched to syngas (where, V(H2):V(CO):V(CO2):V(Ar) = 17.3:6.3:2.1:0.3). The total gas flow rate was 26 mL /min. Here, Ar gas was used as an internal standard. After 30 minutes of flushing the pipelines, slowly the pressure was increase to 3 MPa and then the reaction temperature was raised at 2 °C/min to 250 °C. The reaction gasses were transferred to an online gas chromatograph through the pipeline kept at 120 °C to avoid condensation of organic products. The gas chromatograph (GC-950, Shanghai Haixin Chromatography Instrument Co.) was equipped with a TCD and FID detectors. Among them, the TCD detector was connected to a packed column (1 m, TDX-01 molecular sieve) while the FID detector was connected to a capillary column, DB-624 UI (30 m × 0.32 mm × 1.80 μm). The temperature of inlet, column, FID and TCD were kept at 100 °C, 80 °C, 150 °C and 120 °C, respectively. The TCD detector was used to analyze the gas components such as CO, CO2 and Ar, whereas the FID detector was used to analyze organic components, viz., methanol. After the catalyst enters the working steady state, the reaction conditions were maintained and the sample was analyzed after every 15 min for at least 60 h to observe and record the changes in the catalyst performance. The yield of the methanol was calculated based on the sum of the conversion rates of CO and CO2 calculated by an internal standard method by using the following equations: X C O = ( C O f e e d A r f e e d − C O r e a c t i o n A r r e a c t i o n ) C O f e e d A r f e e d X C O 2 = ( C O 2 f e e d A r f e e d − C O 2 r e a c t i o n A r r e a c t i o n ) C O 2 f e e d A r f e e d Where, X C O and X C O 2 represent the conversion rates of CO and CO2, respectively. C O f e e d , C O 2 f e e d and A r f e e d are the peak areas of the corresponding gasses in the chromatogram before the catalytic reaction, whereas, C O r e a c t i o n , C O 2 r e a c t i o n and A r r e a c t i o n are the corresponding peak areas of each gas in the chromatogram during the reaction. The formula for calculating the space-time yield of methanol is as follows: n C O = Q C O × P R T × φ n C O 2 = Q C O 2 × P R T × φ S T Y MeOH = X C O × n c o + X C O 2 × n C O 2 m cat × M MeOH Where, n C O and n C O 2 represent the molar flow rates of CO and CO2, Q C O and Q C O 2 represent the mole fractions of CO and CO2, respectively in the feed gas. P and T are the calibration pressure and temperature of the mass flow controller. φ represents the feed gas total flow rate. S T Y MeOH stands for the space-time yield of methanol, m cat represents the mass of the catalyst and M MeOH is the relative molecular mass of methanol. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the precursors The XRD patterns of precursors prepared by the standard CP method (Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-CP and Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP) as well as AMOST method (CuxZnyGaz-LDH and CuxZnyAlz-LDH) are given in Fig. 1 . The XRD patterns of the coprecipitated precursors have Ga or Al content =20% and showed the presence of several constituent phases, viz., aurichalcite, malachite and hydrotalcite. The results are in good agreement with the previous ones suggesting the formation of several metal hydroxy carbonate by-phases during synthesis of hydrotalcite-like precursors via CP method [25]. The XRD of Al3+ and Ga3+ containing LDH samples (Fig. 1b) prepared by AMOST method showed typical diffraction peaks at 11.8°, 23.7°, 33.5°, and 60.2° 2θ corresponding to the (003), (006), (009), and (110) crystal planes respectively of hydrotalcite [26] indicating the formation of pure phase hydrotalcite-like precursors using AMOST method. In addition, the broad and asymmetric reflections were also observed at ca. 39° and 47° 2θ corresponding to (015) and (018) crystal planes, respectively. This further indicates that the cations, viz., Cu, Zn, Al/Ga are homogeneously dispersed in the same hydroxide layer [27]. The interlayer spacing of the precursors were calculated from the diffraction of (003) crystal plane [28, 29]. The interlayer spacing of Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDH (2.232 nm) was notably smaller than that of Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDH precursor prepared by using the same AMOST method. Further, it was found that the increase in the content of Ga3+ from 10% to 30% leads to the increase in the interlayer spacing from 2.292 to 2.301 nm. This indicates that increase in Ga3+ in the cationic layers results in a strong electrostatic interaction between the layers owing to the increased amount of stoichiometric intercalated CO3 2− anions. In addition, comparing the diffraction peaks of precursors with different Ga content, it can be seen that the Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDH precursor has more intense diffraction peaks, indicating that when the Ga content is 20%, the precursor hydrotalcite structure is the most complete. The TEM images (Fig. 2 ) show that both Al3+ and Ga3+ containing precursors prepared by the CP method mainly contain mixture of rod-like and irregular sheet-like morphologies. Combined with XRD characterization, it can be concluded that these two samples are comprised of mixed phases, viz., malachite, aurichalcite and hydrotalcite. The TEM of Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDH does not show discrete sheet like structures which is as anticipated. This further support the XRD result which showed the presence of very less intense diffractions of hydrotalcite phase. The Ga3+ ion concentration in Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDH (M2+:M3+ = 9:1) is outside the stability range of LDH which lead to the formation of amorphous precipitates. With increase in the Ga3+ content from 10% to 30% more complete and discrete lamellar structures were formed (Fig. 2), suggesting the formation of stable hydrotalcite phase in Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDH and Cu0.4Zn0.3Ga0.3-LDH precursors, which is consistent with the XRD results. 3.2 Catalyst structural properties The LDH precursors were transformed to the oxides (LDO) by calcination at 330 °C for 3 h and further characterized for XRD, N2 sorption and H2-TPR analyses to evaluate their microstructure properties. The XRD of the calcined catalysts are given in Fig. 3 a and supporting information Fig. S1a. Both Al and Ga containing catalysts prepared by CP method exhibited typical diffraction peaks of CuO and ZnO while the separate diffraction peaks corresponding to Al and Ga were absent indicating that Both the Al and Ga oxides are present as an amorphous or highly dispersed state. The XRD of 10% Ga containing LDO sample, Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDO exhibited the typical crystalline peaks corresponding to CuO and ZnO. The main reason is the poor crystallinity of the Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDH precursor suggesting incomplete cationic layer structure which was destroyed during the subsequent calcination process leading to the formation of separate CuO and ZnO crystal phases. Whereas 20 and 30% Ga containing catalysts showed the broad diffraction peak near 2θ=35°. The XRD and TEM characterizations of the precursors showed that Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDH and Cu0.4Zn0.3Ga0.3-LDH precursors were completely formed single-structured hydrotalcite sheets. Herein, Cu and Zn species are evenly embedded in the cationic layer. Upon calcination, the catalysts still maintain the lamellar morphology due to the ‘topological effect’ [21]. It should be noted that, low temperature calcination did not lead to the formation of spinel structures of constituent metals which is in good agreement with the previous study [30]. The calcined catalysts maintained the mutual dispersion at the atomic level and the typical diffraction peaks of CuO and ZnO cannot be detected in XRD. It further shows that the present AMOST based catalysts consist of uniformly dispersed copper, zinc and Ga domains in the layered structure. The XRD pattern of the Al containing catalyst, Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDO showed typical diffraction peak of ZnO at 2θ=31.8° (Fig. S1a). The TEM of the precursor of this catalyst, Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDH suggested that layered structure is partially destroyed (Fig. 2f). As a result, it can be interpreted that the Zn2+ in the cationic layer, migrates to the surface of the catalyst to form partially aggregated ZnO crystallites which was further supported by XRD results. The N2 sorption isotherms of all the catalysts (Fig. 3b and supporting information Fig. S1b) belong to type IV curve with H3 hysteresis loop indicating that, the pore structure of the catalyst is mainly mesoporous. As compared to coprecipitated catalysts and Al containing LDO catalyst, CuZnGa-LDO catalysts exhibited higher N2 adsorption capacity in the high relative pressure region. The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of the calcined catalysts are given in Table 1 . It was observed that, the catalysts prepared by AMOST method exhibited larger specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter as compared to those prepared from coprecipitation method with similar Cu/Zn/Al or Ga ratio. The results suggested that organic solvent treatment to the hydrotalcite lamellar structure leads to the catalysts with abundant pores. Comparing the textural properties of Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDO and Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO catalysts, it can be seen that Ga is more conducive to the formation of a complete hydrotalcite precursor phase than Al. As a result, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO catalyst exhibits greater specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter. Further, it was found that with increase in Ga content, the specific surface area of CuZnGa-LDO samples was increased from 88 m2•g−1 to 158 m2•g−1 whereas, the pore volume was first increased and then decreased. This indicates that, adding an appropriate amount of Ga is conductive to increase the surface area and pore volume of the catalyst which, eventually is beneficial to the exposure of copper active sites and increase in its contact with the reactant molecules. Surface area of exposed Cu has already shown the incremental effect on the methanol synthesis activity of the Cu/ZnO catalyst [31]. As a result, the N2O chemisorption measurements were conducted to quantify the % dispersion and effective specific surface area of Cu in different catalysts. The results are given in Table 1. Both 20 and 30% Ga containing LDO catalysts exhibited very high surface area and dispersion of Cu. In particular, the effective surface area and dispersion of Cu for Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO catalyst were 116 m2•g−1 and 70%, respectively, which were ca. 2.5 times more than those of the Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP catalyst prepared by the standard co-precipitation method. Combining the results of TEM and XRD of the coprecipitated precursors, it was found that they are mainly composed of mixture of malachite, aurichalcite and hydrotalcite phases which renders the nonuniform distribution of the three metal oxides in the calcined catalysts that leads to a poor Cu surface area and dispersion [13]. However, the pure phase hydrotalcite precursor catalysts prepared by using AMOST method are comprised of highly layered sheets which contain the orderly arrangement of Cu/Zn/Ga metal ions. This leads to the atomic-level mutual dispersion of these ternary oxides which greatly improves the effective specific surface area and dispersion of Cu in the calcined catalyst. In order to explore the chemical state and reducibility of the Cu species before the reaction, different catalysts were characterized by H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 3c, supporting information Fig. S1c). Gaussian fitting was performed on the reduction peaks and the results are given in supporting information Table S1. Since, ZnO, Al2O3 and Ga2O3 will not be reduced by hydrogen within the test range (≤ 350 °C) [32], all the H2 reduction peaks are assigned to the reduction of CuO to Cu0. The reduction peaks could be fitted into two predominant reduction peaks; peak I corresponds to the H2 consumption peak of highly dispersed, easily reducible CuO domains while peak II stands for the H2 consumption peak of bulk CuO domains [14]. It is well known that the metal oxides with smaller particle size and higher dispersion are reduced easily even at low temperature as compared to those in the bulk [33]. It can be seen that the CuO reduction peak I temperature of Cu/Zn/Ga-LDO is reduced nearly by 38 °C than that of Cu/Zn/Al-LDO catalyst, indicating that the addition of Ga is more conducive to improving the reduction ability of CuO. On comparing Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP and Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO catalysts, it was found that under the same composition of copper, zinc and gallium, the relative content of highly dispersed CuO in the catalyst prepared by the AMOST method is higher than that prepared by the co-precipitation method, indicating that the dispersion of copper species in the catalyst prepared by the co-precipitation method is relatively poor, which further supports the XRD and N2O chemisorption results. Further, with increase in Ga content in the LDO samples, the reduction peak temperature of CuO gradually decreases while the content of highly dispersed CuO increases. This is because of the completely formed hydrotalcite layered structure with increasing Ga in the cationic layer resulting in the uniformly distributed Cu, Zn, and Ga species embedded in the exfoliated sheets which is conductive to the better reducibility of CuO domains. The TEM images of all the Al and Ga containing calcined catalysts are given in supporting information Fig. S2. The coprecipitated Al and Ga containing catalysts are comprised of irregular and agglomerated sheets, rods and flake-like morphologies which is in good agreement with the XRD results of the precursors of these catalysts. Further, it was observed that, when the content of Ga is low (10%), the crystallinity of hydrotalcite precursor phase was very poor and upon calcination, it does not lead to the exfoliated sheets rather generates the highly aggregated particles of CuO-ZnO composites. This observation supports the poor dispersion and surface area of Cu observed for 10% Ga containing LDO catalyst. For 20% and 30% Ga containing LDO catalysts, the TEM shows the presence of discrete sheet-like morphology, indicating that after calcination the exfoliated sheets remain quite dispersed and retain lamellar morphology of the layered precursor. It can also be seen that the LDO catalyst surface still retains a richer pore structure, which signify the improved textural properties of these catalysts. The TEM of Al containing LDO catalyst showed apparent lamellar stacking, indicating that Ga can better inhibit the pile up of the sheets and improve Cu dispersion. 3.3 Catalyst adsorption properties In order to further explore the adsorption properties of the catalysts, CO-TPD and H2-TPD was performed over all the Cu/Zn/Ga or Al catalysts (Fig. 4 ). Different adsorption sites on the catalyst surface have different adsorption strength and capacity for CO, as a result, different adsorption curves would appear in the CO-TPD profiles. It is apparent that, all the catalysts showed two predominant CO desorption peaks under 450 °C, which are labeled as α peak (between 50–200 °C) and β peak (between 200–400 °C). The α and β peaks represent weak and strong CO adsorption sites of the catalysts [34]. It can be seen that the CuZnAl and CuZnGa catalysts prepared by coprecipitation mainly contain weakly adsorbed CO, while the catalysts with similar elemental composition prepared by AMOST exhibit predominant CO desorption Peak β at high temperature. It shows that the surface of the catalysts treated with organic solvent show strong CO adsorption capacity. In addition, with the increase of Ga content, the area of the CO desorption peak β first increases and then decreases. The catalyst, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO displayed the highest CO adsorption capacity of 809.0 µmol•gcat −1, indicating that the high dispersion and large effective specific surface area of the active component Cu are beneficial to enhance the strong CO adsorption capacity. The H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts (Fig. 4b) revealed two H2 desorption peaks under 450 °C, viz., peak α and peak β. The α peaks which are located at low temperature between 80–200 °C are attributed to the desorption of weakly adsorbed hydrogen on the catalyst surface whereas, the high temperature desorption β peaks situated between 200–450 °C are associated with the desorption of spill over H atoms from the catalyst surface [35, 36]. It was found that, the catalyst prepared by AMOST method displayed stronger H2 adsorption capacity as compared to those prepared by coprecipitation. Typically, the hydrogen adsorption capacity of the Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO was 302.4 µmol•gcat −1 whereas, the Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP with the identical composition has a H adsorption capacity of 106.6 µmol•gcat −1. The ability of a catalyst to adsorb CO and H2 is related to the rate of methanol synthesis [37]. The stronger ability of the catalyst to adsorb CO and H2 can effectively improve the catalytic performance for methanol synthesis. 3.4 Catalytic activity results The catalyst performance evaluation for hydrogenation of syngas to methanol was carried out on a continuous dual-channel high-pressure fixed-bed microreactor. The space-time yield (STY) of methanol for different catalysts as a function of reaction time on stream is given in Fig. 5 a whereas the steady state STY methanol after 50 h and % stability in STY of methanol formation for different catalysts is given in Fig. 5b. It was found that, both Al and Ga containing LDO catalysts prepared from pure phase LDH exhibited greater STY for methanol formation as compared to those prepared from conventional CP method. Typically, Ga and Al containing coprecipitated catalysts, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP and Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-CP exhibited initial STY of 542 and 512 mg•gcat −1•h−1 which was declined by ca. 26 and 28%, respectively within 50 h of the reaction time. Among LDO samples prepared by AMOST method, all the Ga containing catalysts showed higher STY and greater stability as compared to Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDO catalyst. The initial STY of Al containing LDO catalyst was 617 mg•gcat −1•h−1 which was further declined to 535 mg•gcat −1•h−1 after 50 h of the reaction. Within Ga containing LDO catalysts, the trend in the activity was found to be in the following order, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO > Cu0.4Zn0.3Ga0.3-LDO > Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDO with somewhat similar stability of ca. 93–94% in the activity. Further, on comparing the catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and AMOST method, it was observed that, Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDO catalyst exhibited ∼45% increase in steady state STY and ∼20% increase in stability in the activity as compared to Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-CP. Similarly, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO showed ca. 73% increase in STY with stabilization in the activity by ∼27% as compared to Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP. The results suggest that all the catalysts prepared from AMOST solvent treated LDH precursors show superior performance as compared to those prepared by traditional CP method. 3.5 Structure-activity relationship It is apparent from Fig. 5 that, the catalysts prepared from pure phase LDH precursors by AMOST method show superior performance as compared to those prepared from coprecipitation method. The XRD of the coprecipitated Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-CP and Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-CP precursors (Fig. 1a) suggest that they are composed of several types of mixed- precursors, viz., malachite, aurichalcite and hydrotalcite-like phases. These mixtures are comprised of the varying Cu:Zn ratios in the constituent single phases with varying degree of crystallinity [12]. In addition to that, all the components of the precursor mixture can lead to various domains in the Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 or Al2O3 catalysts with different types of materials with individual textural and catalytic properties. Hence, these domains formed after calcination are not atomically dispersed, resulting in lower Cu effective surface area and Cu dispersion. After reduction, the active component, Cu of these coprecipitated catalysts exhibited larger crystallite size (Table 1) and their ability to adsorb CO and H2 was weak. As a result, these mixed domains make up less active catalytic systems with inhomogeneous microstructures [7]. Further, the TEM of Al containing catalyst, Cu0.4Zn0.4Al0.2-LDO suggested the aggregation of LDO sheets that lead to poor dispersion and surface area of exposed Cu centers which eventually has resulted in poor catalytic performance as compared to the Ga containing catalyst with similar composition. The XRD patterns of the spent catalysts are given in supporting information Fig. S3. The characteristic diffraction peaks of metallic Cu appeared at 43.4°, 50.5°, 74.3° 2θ indicating that, the copper species in the catalyst after the reaction mainly exist in the form of Cu0. Based on the characteristic diffraction peaks at 43.4° and 36.5°, the average crystallite size of Cu and ZnO in the spent catalysts were calculated using the Scherrer formula (Table 1). The effect of Cu crystallite size of the spent CuZnGa-LDO catalysts on the STY of methanol formation has been given in Fig. 6 a. Within the CuZnGa-LDO samples, the Cu crystallite size of spent catalysts was found to be in the following order, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO < Cu0.4Zn0.3Ga0.3-LDO < Cu0.4Zn0.5Ga0.1-LDO, which is exactly opposite to that observed for the methanol formation rate. It was observed that high methanol formation rate was achieved with smaller copper crystallites. The spent catalyst, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO showed smallest Cu0 crystallite size (5.1 nm) even after 50 h on the reaction stream. The particle size modifies the presence of low index (111) and (100) planes, corners and edge atoms that ultimately affect the surface structures as well as electronic properties [38]. The tiny Cu crystallites offers greater number of exposed planes, coordinatively unsaturated atoms and defect sites that promote the adsorption and stabilization of the main reaction intermediates, viz., H3CO, H2CO, etc, [39]. Further, the higher coordination number of Cu has previously shown decrease in the activity for methanol synthesis owing to the sintering of Cu [40]. Moreover, the Cu crystallite size of Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO was much smaller than those catalysts reported from the literature, as shown in Table S2. This may be one of the factors contributed to the excellent catalytic performance as presented in Table S3. The correlation of Cu surface area as well as % Cu dispersion of CuZnGa-LDO catalysts with steady state STY of methanol formation has been given in Fig. 6b. It was found that methanol synthesis rate is directly proportional to the surface area of exposed Cu as well as % Cu dispersion of the catalysts derived from pure phase LDH precursors via AMOST method. In other words, the Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO catalyst with maximum SACu (116 m2/g) and finest % dispersion of Cu (70%) displayed superior methanol formation rate. Our results supported the fact that, organic solvent treatment to the hydrotalcite precursor lead to the catalyst with richer pore structure where, Cu, Zn and Ga components are evenly embedded in the layered structure. Owing to the topological effect, the catalysts still maintain lamellar morphology and the metal oxide domains maintain atomic level mutual dispersion which improve the effective specific surface area and dispersion of exposed Cu in the catalyst. The improved pore structure of the CuZnGa-LDO catalysts lead to the higher adsorption capacity for CO and H2 which is conductive to the methanol synthesis activity. 4 Conclusions A series of Cu/Zn/Ga catalysts were prepared from pure phase hydrotalcite precursors by using AMOST method for catalytic hydrogenation of CO/CO2 to methanol. The formation of pure phase LDH precursors were confirmed by XRD analysis. The XRD and TEM results suggested that 20 and 30% Ga containing LDH precursors were completely formed hydrotalcite-like structures which have resulted in highly improved textural properties and greater reducibility in the corresponding calcined catalysts. The Ga based LDO catalyst showed superior microstructure properties as compared to the Al based LDO ones as well as those prepared from standard coprecipitation route. Notably, CuZnAl-LDO catalyst showed aggregation of layered sheets while CuZnGa-LDO with similar composition showed formation of discrete sheet-like structures. The textural properties further supported that Ga is more conducive to increasing the dispersion of active Cu species in the catalyst than Al. Typically, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO exhibited maximum SACu and % Cu dispersion of 116 m2•g−1 and 70%, respectively. The catalytic evaluation study suggested that, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO is the best performing catalyst for hydrogenation of syngas to methanol and the maximum STY of methanol obtained was 762 mg•gCat −1•h−1 which was deactivated by only ca. 8.6% during 50 h of reaction time on stream. The AMOST method was employed to prepare a completely formed single hydrotalcite-like precursor phase with a richer pore structure. Owing to the "topological effect", the catalyst still maintains the lamellar morphology of the hydrotalcite precursor and the Cu/Zn/Ga oxides maintain atomic-level mutual dispersion, which is beneficial to the dispersion and exposure of active Cu components and eventually to the highly active and stable catalytic performance. Our results clearly demonstrated that, the present synthetic approach is superior than the state-of-the-art coprecipitation route. coredata.dc:description: The small amount of promoter has shown increase in the methanol formation rate by several folds. Hence, hydrotalcite having sufficient trivalent cations are preferred; however, traditional coprecipitation route often leads to poor Cu dispersion owing to higher cationic charge in the layered structure that result in aggregation of the sheets. The present paper reports synthesis of porous, nanostructured Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 catalysts from pure phase hydrotalcite precursors by using aqueous miscible organic solvent treatment method. The 20% Ga containing catalyst showed ca. 2.5-fold increase in both surface area and % dispersion of the exposed Cu as compared to that prepared from standard coprecipitation method with similar composition. The stabilization induced by mutual dispersion of Cu, Zn and Ga components in the exfoliated sheets resulted in confinement of the Cu particle size up to 5 nm in the spent catalyst. The best performing catalyst of the series, Cu0.4Zn0.4Ga0.2-LDO exhibited STY of 762 mg•gCat −1•h−1 for methanol formation from syngas which was decreased by only 8.6% during 50 h of the reaction on stream. Further, it was revealed that, Ga is more conductive to stabilization of Cu as compared to Al, resulting in 23% higher methanol formation rate as compared to the Al containing catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Highly dispersed Cu catalyst based on the layer confinement effect of Cu/Zn/Ga-LDH for methanol synthesis
